Package org.hypermedea

Class HypermedeaArtifact

java.lang.Object
cartago.Artifact
org.hypermedea.HypermedeaArtifact
public class HypermedeaArtifact extends cartago.Artifact

A Hypermedea artifact submits agent requests to servers and processes any incoming response (synchronous or asynchronous). It also manages a collection of resource representations available to any agent observing the artifact.

In most applications, a single Hypermedea artifact will be enough. A typical JCM project file will be as follows: 

mas example_mas {

 agent example_web_agent {
   join: example_workspace
   focus: example_workspace.h
 }

 workspace example_workspace {
   artifact h: org.hypermedea.HypermedeaArtifact()
 }

}

Agent example_web_agent focuses on artifact h, to be able to execute its operations and observe the resource representations it manages. Available operations are get, watch, put, post, patch and delete.

All operations have in common that they accept a form as input, i.e. a set of arbitrary property/value pairs (called form fields). A form may be used to provide further arguments to the operation, such as custom headers, or to provide protocol-specific information, such as an MQTT Quality of Service (QoS) level or a ROS message type. All operations also have an alternative signature without form, which is equivalent to executing the operation with an empty form.

    • init

      Overrides:
      dispose in class cartago.Artifact

    • get

      public void get(String resourceURI)
      Executes get(String, Object[]) with an empty form.

    • get

      public void get(String resourceURI, Object[] formFields)

      Asks the server for a representation of resourceURI. Once the artifact receives a response from the server, it exposes the response payload as an observable property (a Jason literal) before returning. The calling agent can thus safely query the resource's representation after the call returns, as follows: 

      +!retrieve_then_query(URI) <-
    h.target(URI, TargetURI) ;
    get(URI) ;
    for (rdf(URI, P, O)[source(TargetURI)) {
      .print("Found: ", P, O)
    } ;
  .

      Any piece of representation found in the server's response will be turned into a literal with a source annotation. In some cases, the URI provided by the agent may not be the exact target used by the artifact to request the server (URI fragments are e.g. stripped away). This is why Hypermedea also provides the target internal action to extract the corresponding target from any URI.

      Note that a resource representation may correspond to one or more literals, depending on the response payload's Content-Type. In RDF, it is indeed more convenient for programmers to have access to RDF triples individually rather than as members of a list, whereas in JSON, there is a single literal with a tree-shaped structure. See ct for details on representation handlers.

      Parameters:
      resourceURI - the URI of a resource
      formFields - a collection of form fields (key/value pairs), to parameterize the operation, the protocol binding or the payload binding

    • watch

      public void watch(String resourceURI)
      Executes watch(String, Object[]) with an empty form.

    • watch

      public void watch(String resourceURI, Object[] formFields)

      Subscribes to any change in the representation of resourceURI, to be sent asynchronously by the server. Not all protocols may support this operation type. Plain HTTP, for instance, doesn't.

      In contrast to a get operation, the call may return before having received any representation from the server. The call returns as soon as the server confirms the request has been processed (or, if the underlying protocol has no acknowledgement mechanism, it may return immediately). The caller agent should therefore wait for events corresponding to server notifications, as follows: 

      +!watch_only(URI) <-
    h.target(URI, TargetURI) ;
    watch(URI) ;
    +watching(TargetURI) ;
  .

+rdf(S, P, O)[source(TargetURI)] : watching(TargetURI) <-
     .print("Received: ", S, P, O) ;
  .

      or, if a single notification is enough: 

      +!watch_then_wait(URI) <-
    h.target(URI, TargetURI) ;
    watch(URI) ;
    .wait({ +(json(Val)[source(TargetURI) }) ;
    .print("Received: ", Val) ;
  .

      In the above example, the agent must know in advance what Content-Type to expect. Certain protocol bindings have limitations as to what Content-Type can be exchanged with the server. In case the server supports it, though, the agent may leverage content negotiation to request the server to return a specific Content-Type.

      target is a Hypermedea internal action, wait is part of the Jason standard library.

      Parameters:
      resourceURI - the URI of a resource
      formFields - a collection of form fields (key/value pairs), to parameterize the operation, the protocol binding or the payload binding

    • put

      public void put(String resourceURI, String representation)
      Executes put(String, String, Object[]) with an empty form.

    • put

      public void put(String resourceURI, String representation, Object[] formFields)

      Asks the server to replace the current representation(s) it has of resourceURI with the provided representation. This parameter must be provided as a Jason literal, in order to be serialized in a standard format by the proper representation handler (see package ct).

      After the call returns, the caller agent may assume the new representation of resourceURI on server side is the provided one. There is however no strict guarantee. The server may also alter this representation, e.g. to maintain consistency with other resources it manages or to add metadata (modification date, author, etc.). This is why the Hypermedea artifact makes no assumption about what the new representation is. If the caller agent wants to cache the new representation, it should execute a get operation right after the put, as follows: 

      +!put_then_get(URI) <-
    h.target(URI, TargetURI) ;
    put(URI, json(5)) ;
    get(URI) ;
    // the artifact may then expose json(5)[source(TargetURI)]
    // or, for instance, json([kv("value", 5), kv("modified", 1700304346)])[source(TargetURI)]
  .

      By default, the Hypermedea artifact deletes the outdated representation of resourceURI when the call returns.

      Parameters:
      resourceURI - the URI of a resource
      representation - a resource representation to send to the server, in the form of a Jason literal
      formFields - a collection of form fields (key/value pairs), to parameterize the operation, the protocol binding or the payload binding

    • post

      public void post(String resourceURI, String representationPart)
      Executes post(String, String, Object[]) with an empty form.

    • post

      public void post(String resourceURI, String representationPart, Object[] formFields)

      Asks the server to append the provided representationPart to the current representation of resourceURI. As for put, it is not guaranteed that the server does exactly what the agent asked. It may remove other parts of the representation to maintain consistency or add more information to it.

      Notably, a server may also create a new resource as a side effect of the operation. This new resource should either be linked from the (new) representation of resourceURI, if its Content-Type supports hypermedia, or be exposed in a message header, hidden by the protocol binding. For instance, in response to a POST request, an HTTP server may return a 201 Created response that includes a Location header pointing to the new resource. To expose this information to the caller agent, the Hypermedea artifact builds an RDF triple from the location header and adds it to the representation of resourceURI. The agent may then query that RDF triple, as follows: 

      +!post_then_follow_link(URI) <-
    h.target(URI, TargetURI) ;
    post(URI, json(5)) ;
    ?(rdf(TargetURI, "related", CreatedResourceURI)) ;
    .print("Created resource: ", CreatedResourceURI) ;
    h.target(CreatedResourceURI, CreatedTargetURI) ;
    get(CreatedResourceURI) ;
    ?(json(Val)[source(CreatedTargetURI)]) ;
    .print(Val) ; // should include "5"
  .

      In the above example, the related predicate is set by default. However, in some cases, protocol bindings may choose a more precise predicate, if the context permits it (for instance dct:hasPart).

      Note that, as for put, if the Hypermedea artifact had a representation of resourceURI before the operation, this representation is deleted when the call returns.

      Parameters:
      resourceURI - the URI of a resource
      representationPart - part of a resource representation to send to the server, in the form of a Jason literal
      formFields - a collection of form fields (key/value pairs), to parameterize the operation, the protocol binding or the payload binding

    • patch

      public void patch(String resourceURI, String representationDiff)
      Executes patch(String, String, Object[]) with an empty form.

    • patch

      public void patch(String resourceURI, String representationDiff, Object[] formFields)

      Asks the server to apply a diff on the current representation of resourceURI, as specified in representationDiff. A diff should specify what parts to remove and what parts to add to the representation. Examples of diff formats include SPARQL Update and Git diff (for text files).

      Not fully implemented yet.

      Parameters:
      resourceURI - the URI of a resource
      representationDiff - a diff to apply to the resource's representation, in the form a Jason literal
      formFields - a collection of form fields (key/value pairs), to parameterize the operation, the protocol binding or the payload binding

    • delete

      public void delete(String resourceURI)
      Executes delete(String) with an empty form.

    • delete

      public void delete(String resourceURI, Object[] formFields)

      Asks the server to delete all known representations of resourceURI. The Hypermedea artifact does delete all representations locally, as there is no ambiguity as to what should happen on the server. However, other resources may have altered representations after the operation, which the artifact is unaware of. For instance, the server might delete all references of the resource in the representation of other resources it manages.

      Parameters:
      resourceURI - the URI of a resource
      formFields - a collection of form fields (key/value pairs), to parameterize the operation, the protocol binding or the payload binding
